comments.commentBody:
RE: WHY DO YOU PERSECUTE ME?

There is nothing wrong with dreaming of coming to America (that’s the United States of America, not the American Continent). Millions, maybe billions of people on this planet have that same dream. Your problem was putting you and your family above others as if they don’t count.

There is a process that law abiding future immigrants must and are willing enough to follow. It is called legal immigration. They don’t make excuses. They wait their turn. They don’t choose to break into our country, steal a citizen’s job, steal a citizen’s benefits, and steal a citizen’s place in school. You put yourself above the citizena of this country, and think asking for forgiveness is all it takes. Millions of you are stealing our treasury and our country and this is not forgivable.

I believe that the situation on the US-Mexico is incredibly dangerous and volatile. While I believe in a centerist-left policy I believe the border situation needs to handled now. With the rise of the Mexican drug cartels, violence has lept up all along the border. If we don't do something now we could have a situation in which gangs control most of area through intimidation. We should call in the National Guard to secure the border. We shold also seek ways of preventing illegal immigrants from attempting the crossing in the first place.

While I agree that the situation on the border is tense and that the laws of our nation are being disrespected, I disagree with getting rid of  citizenship by birth. If we get rid of it, which would require an amendment to the constitution, what defines absolute citizenship? I am an American by birhright. So what happens if birthright citizenship is removed? Will the government be able to remove my citizenshp status and thus my ability to vote, if I disagree with them? The abuse you speak of is nonexsistent. That is to say irrelevant. If you're born in the United States, even two feet from the border, you are an American citizen and my fellow countrymen. I believe that it is one right, that if changed, would be the biggest mistake the US has ever made.

There is no way that someone who has not been in combat can understand the depth of this problem.  Whether this works or not, whether there is an abundance of fraud or not, it is at least an attempt of real recognition for the suffering and the sacrifice made by young men and women for the good of their country---even if, or especially if, the war was wrong.  It is a worthy attempt to set things right.  This attempt will not be perfect but I greatly applaud the effort.

People with disabling PTSD from non-documented combat (e.g. truck drivers) or even combat often have personality disorders that predate their military service.  I have treated a number of people with PTSD who intensely engage in treatment until they get their VA or SSD disability benefit and monthly check and then disappear, either being cured or at least not being in enough distress to continue treatment.
Also, many people with diagnosed PTSD suffer from distress but are NOT disabled; thus it is no surprise that there are 150000 diagnoses but only 78000 people deemed disabled.

For the individual who posted #23. It's my understanding that in WWII, PTSD was called Combat Fatigue. I'm not sure about Korea, but the general idea of PTSD did come to light following the Vietnam War. I served in Vietnam in 1966-67, was where Agent Orange was sprayed, and have been awarded a Purple Heart. I draw no disability; have not applied for it; and to this date, have had no problems with any of the aforementioned. My wounds were not that bad, so I felt no need to ask to compensation. I have never had a flashback, nightmares, hurt anyone, nor have I had any problems related to Agent Orange. I'm often questioned what PTSD really is, or if we really know. I was in an infantry unit, USMC; saw my share of combat and had friends die. I guess I consider myself fairly lucky not to suffer from any aftereffects.
As far as what the VA is now considering doing; I think all our veterans deserve what they are due, but I hope this doesn't become Pandora's Box.
To all that serve, and have served: A salute to each of you.
Now this is money well-spent!  Bravo to the VA!  Our vets should be our most cared for group.

"I'm not childish enough to believe that everyone who applies is legitimate."

No, your callous enough to deny those what is their due all over the simple minded assumption that so many are going to cheat the system that some sort of socialist Armageddon is just around the corner or its going to break YOUR bank. If it can’t be the model of fraud prevention than throw it out the window seems to be your attitude. If that’s the public standard than kiss your homestead tax write offs and farm subsidies good bye. Let me point this out, I can give you a list and provide public record of people who need this care and don’t get it (frontline.org to name one).

Where is your (credible) documentary on the rampant horde of 21 year olds sucking the life out of society with fraudulent claims? You are right about one thing, you have no idea what you are talking about. These 21 year olds have been at war. You have been at the mall.

I’ll make a wager without examining any statistics: there are more dead 21 year olds than those who are filing fraudulent claims through the VA.

"If you've been to one VA, you've been to 1 VA."

The care - and diagnoses - can vary from VA to VA. There is the infamous email from a psychologist in some Texas VA lamenting the diagnosis of PTSD as almost a sham. I have seen veterans who qualify as PTSD by one VA (in one region) but almost denied in another (another region). It's not clear if the problem is the professional, the region, or the tincture of time and therapy.

Ever been to the VA?

Am I wrong here, its nice to say all of this, but too long have they uttered this kind of crap and in reality, those same soliders feel abandoned. Sure, you serve in Iraq, come home since your tour is up, what, you lost your job, no worries..
You might have 26 weeks, oh its ok, you get to go back to Iraq or maybe Afghanistan.

Then you have a Senate who sits and takes a week vaction, nice huh. WHile millions are unemployed, of course they don't mention all the guardsmen and women who come hokme to this two party broken down system.

I suffered a TBI in 1991, and I pity the folls (Mr. T talking) who believe that anything less that 5 years of hard recovery will do, PTSD is just a minor point. As the comments have said, its hell to pay, for the family. How many years did they say this was crap, like Agent Orange and Desert Storm cough.

I guess I rather hope the VA will change, for me, I dont go, it reminds me of Nurse Katchet from One flew over....

Charley Miller
unaffiliated

sorry if I am ranting, I take this personally, myhearts and prayers go to our troops
VA 100% service connected disability pensions are totally inadequate given today's cost of living.
If the American Psychological Association supported this, one can bet the fraud will be rampant.

With the Climategate emails revealed and the very nature of losing the Medieval Warming and the Little Ice Age in research and his statistical chart the guy is fishy. In this case where the results appear intended to push an agenda whose cost would be off the scale to the world economy, a little bit of fraud of this type could make the real relative cost of Burnie Madoff look like a bargain.

If there is form-fitting going on, it is fraud on a massive policy level scale. It's not like quite a few "scientist" advocates have not called for exaggeration and scary stories, hiding their doubts and other clearly dishonest forms of political science.

Scientific fraud, manipulation of data, form-fitting and a host of other human weaknesses happen. They often happen when ambition outstrips talent, or when a political science agenda is allowed to contaminate a researcher's mind.

@Johan B. (#7) -- re: your comment about the aggressiveness of van Bommel (which I raised earlier), you wrote: "it is downright hypocrisy to hear Americans complain about the level of aggression." etc etc etc...

Hmmm... For a start, I'm not American. Not born here, not a naturalized citizen either. Believe it or not, here in Chicago, just as in LA or NY, etc, there are millions of non-Americans living here with Americans, and have been for a long time -- just imagine that if you can! But what bothers me most about your rant is the assumption that the US government and its countless acts of violence directly represent the "violent mindset" of ALL Americans and all the people that live in the US (who therefore have no right to complain about van Bommel's aggression, etc). That's insane. It would be like saying that someone named "Johan" must be directly complicit with the history of deep-seated European racism responsible for a century of murder worldwide. I hope you'd agree with me in seeing that's insane.

But your rant aside, I just want to go back to my earlier comment about the blog post and say: The Dutch style of play has definitely changed, and yes, Van Bommel is an aggressive, cynical and self-aggrandizing "cleaner" (what a disgusting term!) who degrades the spirit of the game.

"This is the only thing that can explain the complacent feet of their goalkeeper, Maarten Stekelenburg, who was too slow to shuffle across his area when Diego Forlán struck"

No.

Watch the replay. Forlán's shot caught Stekelenburg moving to his right when he needed to be left. Poor anticipation by Stekelenburg, or brilliant anticipation by Forlán, or dumb luck are all possible explanations for the goal. Complacent feet? No.

More than any other sport, football invites conspiracy theories. Maybe more than all other sports combined, the conspiracy theory rules the football roost. As a football fan of well over 30 years duration, I have seen some strange ones, and some plausible ones. In the aftermath of Germany's 4-0 thrashing of Argentina, there was this from a guy called PW Stewart from England:

"Since 1996 I have been publicizing my theory that the EU fixes certain sporting events to boost morale for key EU States. In 1998 the STEWART SYSTEM predicted a French World Cup win to bounce France into the Euro. In 2006 Italy was close to leaving the Euro. I predicted (in the Letters Pages of the Southampton Daily Echo 8th July) that Italy would win on penalties (I’ve posted this letter separately). This year German morale has collapsed. Germans are tired of supporting the failing Euro and Germany is close to leaving. The whole future of the Euro and the EU hinges on a German victory. The stakes are enormous! To stop Germany leaving the Euro, the EU must boost German morale URGENTLY. Germany MUST win. There is no other outcome. But the real tragedy is that when Germany is holding the World Cup aloft for the whole German nation to see, you won’t believe a word of this. File it for future contemplation!"

I guess we can all file it alright. Had your conspiracy theory had even the slightest shred of credibility, don't you think that the ref would have given the penalty in favor of Ozil at the end of the first half? Now THAT would have been something-a match without a single foul for over 25 minutes (NEVER have I seen that occur in over 30 years), a match overwhelmingly dominated teritorially and in shots by Spain. And there was your golden chance for Germany to break on top right at the end of the half.
Given how bad the refereeing has been in general, although today I thought the ref was pretty good, I think that is incumbent upon all of us to stop imputing bad intention onto simple incompetence, and the overall difficulty of refereeing top flight football with a single central referee and only two assistants.

The elevated CO2 levels didn't have any measurable effect on climate as of yet, measurements show. The climate system was stable enough to compensate for the small extra greenhouse effect.

- the climate models failed in such a spectacular way to predict or explain the satellite shown 12 years of global cooling
- new facts which turn our models upside down about the ocean circulation or the methane balance come up regularly
These all show that the climate system is much more complicated than thought.

Most of the climate system is not understood or measured. Important forcings like the Sun radiation are not predictable in sufficient detail on the long run.

Most importantly the system shows constant signs that it is nonlinear. What this means is one cannot treat its average - the climate - separate from the details - the weather.

My estimate as a mathematical physicist is that the system has a chance to be meaningfully modeled not earlier than 50-100 years from now, if ever. There is nothing to show that predicting the average global temperature 100 years from now to +-2C is any easier than predicting the weather 1 year from now to +-2C all around the world (we can do it about 3-4 days ahead with that precision now.)

The historical temperature trend is clear, though.

There is a well documented millennial oscillation - the Chinese just documented in multiple ways a medieval warm at least as high as now, probably higher. That gives a 1C/century rise in the last few centuries.

There is a well documented multidecadal - 60 year oscillation - which gave the 1910-1938 warming, the 1938-1970 cooling, the 1970-1998 warming by the same amount as before 0.8C, and now the 1998- present cooling. This oscillation has been documented in multiple ways over centuries.

Most importantly it has predicted the current temperature trends well. The IPCC models have all failed to predict the temperature behavior for 12 years now - 1/8 of the century they were supposed to model.

*******************************************

The CRU fellows just wanted to make a fuss about nothing unusual in the measurements - that's why they had such a hard time doing it.

The climate mitigation measures of all kinds cost the Brits about 50 billion pounds a year. That's about $8000/year for a family with the typical higher than average income of this blog reader.

Would you want to give your grandchildren a state of permanent recession aimed at mitigating a climate trend which follows, unperturbed, its cycles?

I would give another read to the actual emails before committing to the same in the US.

All emails
http://eastangliaemails.com/

Selected emails
http://www.free-the-memes.net...

I love doing this - I actually wanted Spain to win but the ol' Marxist in me begs the question:

"Exactly how many jobs will this World Cup create for Spain, and will it be able to pull them out of that horrible hole they're heading into (á la Greece)? I'm sure the WC Title will be glorious for los Rojos but think about it, the world will still be the same the day after and they will still go home to a country about to collapse. If this saves them, then I'm wrong - but otherwise, cheer while you can."

Boom.

I wonder if commenters 1-8 will have the grace to eat their words?  And the (rabid, resentful) condescension in some of these comments is quite breathtaking (clearly not about football/soccer).  Thanks, on the other hand, to commenters 115, 124, and 138 (among several others) for the open-minded, lucid, illuminating analysis.
Go Messi!  Oh wait, nevermind.
WHAT HAPPENED to all the comments? At 5 PM there were already more than 25...

UGH...

spain thoroughly dominated possession of this game but beautiful it's not. i'm afraid i'm not going to be happy if they win the WC. the spanish have drained all the joy and beauty of soccer. they score 1 goal per game, choke the life out of the midfield, and defend like crazy. that's their winning formula. win games they can, but it's boring and not fun to watch. compare that with the germans and dutch -- much more enjoyable to watch. now, that's football.

i'm afraid i'm going dutch sunday.
Hey Johan, nice rant about violence/America/sports. The writer of this article though is, I believe, a Brit.

@131, strong silence,

reckless was the kindest word i could find. he seriously hurt another player. you don't play soccer like that unless it's in the bush league. that was felonious at least. this referee gave mueller a yellow for a barely there unintentional handball -- the same punishment for someone who almost broke an opponent's face and teeth?
